comment_text:
Some people in the comments (hey people!) have stated the Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapsed due to aeroelastic flutter rather than resonance. I found this idea really interesting and it took me down a rabbit hole of nuanced physics. 

There’s a common misconception that the bridge collapsed because of resonance in a particular way. Namely, that the wind pushed, then stopped, then pushed, then stopped at just the right rate to match the natural frequency of the bridge. This did not happen. 

What happened is that relatively steady wind pushed on the bridge, the elastic properties of the bridge caused the bridge to twist/sway, and that process repeated, and occurred at the natural frequency of the bridge. This is an example of a process called self-oscillation, and the self-oscillation that resulted was at the natural frequency of the bridge. This is quite different from “forced resonance” where the driving force is at the same frequency as the natural frequency of the system. The question I’m considering is whether the bridge scenario can be considered a type of resonance. We call it “resonance” when you blow into a bottle and it whistles. In that situation, there’s no periodic driver. There’s a constant force, just like with the bridge.

I have been a die hard audiophile for around 15 years now and I`m telling you that, with my own equipment that`s cost under $10 000 over the years, I could absolutely find a resonant frequency eventually. You have to keep in mind that when tuning and trying to find the sensitivity and/or resonant frequency of a speaker, you must count the volume the speakers are putting out. The odd time you can listen to a song at a low volume, and it`ll sounds amazing, bassy, anything you can ask for, but the second you go to turn it up it`ll lose quality. The reason being is everything comes into play when it comes to audio. Everything from the resting air pressure in the room, to the temperature. Placement is another huge factor. If your subwoofer isn`t placed correctly in a room, you may not even hear it but you`ll be able to feel and hear it on the other side of your house. If you really want to try and find the resonant frequency of human body parts, the only way I can think of doing so is to have a nice high power subwoofer in a symmetrical room with sound insulation on the walls ceiling and floor, and then try a certain frequency, if you have no luck, move the subwoofer around the room until you do. Still no luck? I`d bump it up 2hz every time, still making sure to move the subwoofer around the room. It might take days or weeks to find the perfect placement and frequency, but theoretically that would be how you`d do it. How I`d do it anyways I`m not a scientist and don`t have equipment to measure such things for me.

That was curious. Frequency output of sub-woofers is not typically cut off like that. Probably you were experiencing the -6db and -3db roll-off, so it will reduce the 15-20 db signal amplitude. (A speaker rated at 15 db should produce 15db.) So that is curious. Maybe a software cut-off? Maybe an electronic crossover is to blame?

There is no good reason to put a low-pass filter in the low freq region of sub speaker. It would complicate the circuit for no benifit. The upper frequency band would have one because of wave cancellations between the perimeter of the woofer cone and its center. That's just a radius thing. But that should be it.

The Vas (volume of air displacement of the cone) will level the output due to resistance of the air mass that cone is asked to move. This being the piston effect, of course.

Bottom line: something probably went wrong with the procedure, not the speaker itself. So you could still get an eyeball to vibrate. I highly doubt those PA speakers can do anything below 35hz. They're PA subwoofers. Made to be loud, not go low. You want low bass? Go to an iMax. Or use a rotary subwoofer. Or put two SVS PB-16 ultras in a small room. Or 2 Monolith M-215s.

Achieving true low bass is very difficult and potentially expensive (but that's relative). A subwoofer that can do a proper 15hz tone in a large room costs about $3000 on average. Making a speaker go that low is very difficult. You can't just use lots of power. That will only get you lots of volume. What you need is a large, long throw speaker, in a large enclosure, with a long port. But that's not always the case. It'a just complicated. But I can guarantee one thing: Those speakers even coming close to 20hz is very optimistic.

And on a side note: I don't get why venues don't use home subwoofers. They're about the same price, they're loud, they have better sound quality, and they go much lower. If I owned a venue, I'd get a Monolith M-215 or 2 depending on how large it is, and call it a day. Low, loud bass for days.

An interesting phenomenon to discuss is that of Schumann resonances, something that mostly occurs at ELF frequencies with electromagnetic waves. Amateur Radio operators will be familiar with radio wave propagation, where radio waves (especially in the HF bands) are reflected by the Earth's ionosphere, allowing long distance communications. At certain ELF frequencies this space between the earth and the ionosphere acts as a waveguide and it is possible to create a standing wave all the way around the earth.

As it would turn out, the world is very loud in infrasonic ranges- on the order of 85db average. As observed by the folks that invented the mp3, you only perceive the loudest 10% of sounds that you hear- why you can't hear a finger snap beneath a thunderclap, even though both sounds impart vibrations to your eardrum. Well, as it turns out, natural processes like weather and geologic processes produce rather loud sounds in the ranges below 10 hertz, and so our hearing evolved to not be affected by those sounds, so that we could hear very minute sounds. It is a commonly held belief that human beings cannot hear frequencies above 20khz- but the most modern thinking with regard to that limit says that while I might not be able to directly hear a 21khz tone, that the sound field occurring in those higher frequencies still affects the perception of sounds below the 20khz threshold. I found a great article discussing this aspect of hearing: http://recordinghacks.com/articles/the-world-beyond-20khz/

I design professional loudspeakers for high output applications - I can tell you for sure that it's not so easy to get such high pressure that low down in a large space like that, especially from the typical 218 reflex enclosures as shown in this video. It would require around 125dB that low down to do anything interesting, which is not an easy task for sustained periods due to thermal limitations of the coil/magnet assembly, or short periods even, as the drivers can only move so far before mechanical failure occurs.

Conventional bass loudspeakers are designed for linearity and output over a useful, musical bandwidth. Much of the time, this is 30Hz -3db point, relative to it's output in much of the best case scenarios, as anything lower at higher output becomes too large and inconvenient to transport. A good example of a sub frequency loudspeaker for this purpose would be the Danley Matterhorn, which is rather large. A more cost effective method of generating one particular frequency would be to build a tuned resonant pipe/horn, which uses air as a driver opposed to displacement caused by back and fourth motion of a piston. Much like a pipe organ, but larger. If anyone was interested to read my comment this far, take a look at the work of Valdimir Gavreau - infrasound at such levels is dangerous, especially if you find the resonance of your body, but super interesting!!! :D

If your precision on the eyeball shaking resonance was as wide as 2 Hz steps, then it's not surprising you didn't feel it.
In the resonance demonstration I use in class (a mass on a spring connected via spring to a driver), the resonance response is sensitive to within a couple tenths of a Hz.
IDK if this would make the difference to feel it, honestly, but I have reason to suspect that the resonance frequency is more sensitive than a 2 Hz jump could "tune in."

The lower limit of frequency a headphone or even most affordable computer speakers are rated at is nowadays in the mid 40 Hz range. Unfortunate because the most common bass note in pop/rock/metal/punk guitar is the low-E, which is 41.2 Hz. Technically below the cutoff of these speakers, though they can still produce that note, just attenuated (quieter) than it was meant to be in the sound mix.
If you like music that uses a 5-string bass, then the low note can go down to about 30 Hz, which is just slightly above the lowest note on an 88-key piano.
The odds that most listeners' speakers can produce those 5 Hz, 15 Hz, 20 Hz, tones is pretty slim, unless they're audiophiles or bass players.

In case people are like, I can hear lower notes than that with my EarPods, that's because if you play a note, and another note a fifth higher, you will hear a note an octave below the first note.  So, a 65 hz note, plus a 97.39 hz note (approx), could be heard as a 32.5 hz note.  For reference, the lowest note on a normal piano is 27.5 hz, and the lowest note on a normal bass (electric bass guitar), is 41.2 hz (approx), so you know they have to do something to let us hear those notes.  They create the illusion of them with that fifth trick.

First the easy one. Oobleck is cornstarch and water, not flour and water.
Second, loudspeakers operating properly will only make the flame vibrate. It is only when they start to distort, in other words become nonlinear, that they can make air movement in one direction. The fact that these speakers were blowing out the candles merely indicates that they were badly distorting the sound.
The equations for sound have a component with a mathematical imaginary value, indicated by multiplying by i. It is this component that measures the amount of nonlinear movement, i.e. what most folx simply call "wind".

Tacoma Narrows Bridge failure was more due to aerodynamic flutter, than resonance. When the bridge would twist one way, the wind would catch it like a wing and twist it even further that way, then as swung back the other direction, the wind catch it and push it even further the other way. It seems like a distinction without a difference, but in a resonance system, the frequency stays the pretty much the same while the amplitude grows. With this type of flutter, it doesn't oscillate at the fundamental resonant frequency of the object, but is pushed either faster or slower frequency by the aerodynamic forces. The frequency of flutter depends on the shape of the object, wind speed and the vortices thrown off the object. All manner of small things can stop or exasperate flutter, without really affecting the resonant frequency.

Hi, Sound engineer here, I just want to add that speaker designers and sound engineers do care about frequencies below 20hz because they can actually be detrimental to the performance of a speaker. If allow infrasonic frequencies, you will be reducing the amount of speaker travel that is available for audible sound. The speaker can only move so far in either direction, so you need to use that motion efficiently.

Those speakers probably could do 15hz, but just couldn't do enough SPL to notice at that frequency with the enclosure they were in. What frequency the speaker enclosure is tuned to matters a lot when it comes to the extreme low end. Most subwoofer enclosures are tuned to resonate higher, like 80-120hz and multiples of that. A custom made enclosure could be made to resonate much lower, but it probably wouldn't sound as good.

What I'm saying is, yes, there is some math involved in making a speaker enclosure that sounds good. You can't just stuff some premium speakers in a pre-made box and expect it to sound like it did in the display.

According to Google's documentation, the option for audio codecs used to encode YT videos are either AAC or MP3. [ 1 ]
AAC, without loss of generality, operates from 8 kHz to 96 kHz vs that of MP3 which is 16 kHz to 48 kHz. [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
While AAC does offer LFE, I do not believe they are being re-encoded at those sampling rates given YT's specifications. [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
Looking at the Stats for Nerds, I noticed the Vorbis and Opus codecs.


Finally, Opus tops out around 160 kbit/s which is not enough to support something as low as 15 Hz. [ 3 ] [ 4 ]


[ 1 ] https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/2853702?hl=en
[ 2 ] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Audio_Coding
[ 3 ] https://www.telosalliance.com/support/MP3-And-AAC-Explained
[ 4 ] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opus_(audio_format)#Quality_comparison_and_low-latency_performance

A 5Hz wave is HUGE!! Speed of sound in air is 1,125fps so a 1,125 Hz sine wave is ~1 ft.
A 50Hz wave is ~22 ft and a 5Hz wave is about 225 feet tall! So if you think about the room you were in, if it's 50ft long you can only get ONE 25Hz wave in the room and anything below that is basically below the cutoff frequency. Therefore: You basically need to do the 5Hz test OUTSIDE. Or in the VAB! :D If you want to come to Baltimore, we can find a way to do the 5Hz test :)

My take on the candle problem oscillation and flattening is this:
The soundwave propagating is causing the oscillation because the fire is basically hot gas and oscillating just like nearby air.
And the fact that the flame is moving flattens it, just like when you walk with a candle: The already hot air has a form of inertia. It's not really moving horizontally with the candle (or just the flame in this case), so it "bends" the flame (lower part following the candle and higher part staying in place), and the fact that the flame keeps moving prevents it from heater higher air and thus "flattens the flame". I'm willing to bet that shaking lightly a candle produces the same flattening (although it's just a wild guess)

The Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapse is a case of Aerodynamic Fluttering, not Resonance. There is a subtle difference there. Resonance is an amplified response to an external force... you'd get a given amplification for a given frequency. Fluttering implies self-excitation... the deformation of the bridge generates a force on the structure (elastic recovery + gravity ) which results in a larger deformation, which results in a larger force etc.
